results.title: Exam technique: economics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Offers specialised exam preparation advice for economics students. Discusses the weeks prior to the exam, strategies for the night before, format and use of time in the exam itself, multiple choice and short answer questions and essay choice and planning.

results.title: Ex Nilalang
results.brief_description:
Ex Nilalang is a cumulative moving image project by Australian-Filipino collective Club Ate, founded by multidisciplinary video and performance artists, Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra. Three episodes were created in 2015 and ACMI is proud to have commissioned the fourth for Asia TOPA.

The work seeks to transform existing Filipino mythologies that were once used to demonise queer identities by colonial powers. ‘Nilalang’, which means both ‘to create’ and ‘creature’, describes the work’s transformation of existing mythologies and its imagining of future folklore.

The artists draw from their own narratives, lived experiences and personal relationships to forge new connections between queer, migrant, spiritual and intercultural experiences.

This latest video portrait will also screen alongside the first three episodes ‘Balud’, ‘Dyesebel’ and ‘Lolo ex Machina’ in ACMI’s cinemas as part of its regular ART+FILM program on Wednesday 1 March at 6.30pm, followed by a conversation with Justin Shoulder and Bhenji Ra.

production_dates.notes:
This project is supported by the KMATS Endowment Fund and Arts Centre Melbourne for Asia TOPA.

Asia TOPA is a joint initiative of the Sidney Myer Fund and Arts Centre Melbourne and is supported by the Australian and Victorian Governments.

results.title: Evolutionary fantasy: Bolero by Maurice Ravel from Allegro n
results.creator_credit: Bruno Bozzetto and Bruno Bozzetto Films
results.brief_description: In this animated segment from the feature film “Allegro non troppo”. Ravel’s “Bolero” accompanies a satiric fantasy of the evolution of life beginning with an amoebic blob emerging from a coke bottle.

results.title: Evolution of the Australian crawl
results.brief_description: The Australian crawl stroke is demonstrated and compared with other styles used in free style swimming. A series of re-enactments, using champions of the past and present, (Beaurepaire and Charlton) show the developments of the style from its first known use in Australia by Wickham. The film also demonstrates variations on the crawl stroke.

results.title: Evolution by natural selection
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: Professor M.J.Pentz interviews Dr. S.M. Manton who is involved in breeding cats. She shows some of the cats resulting from 8 generations of selection and inter- and cross-breeding, and explains some of the methods used in artificial selection. Dr. R.M. Holmes and Dr. M.E. Varley then illustrate the effect of natural selection on natural populations, by presenting some observations on the ratio of normal and melanic forms of peppered moth in industrial and non-industrial areas of Britain

results.title: Evolution
results.brief_description: A sly, funny “survey” of evolution from the earth’s beginnings till now. Sophisticated enough to entrance adult audiences, this film’s rollicking, outrageous humour will delight children. An intriguing discussion starter for biology and social studies courses. Finalist, American Film Festival 1981: Humour & Satire.

results.title: Evolution
results.brief_description: An animated film telling the story of how life came into being on this planet. The animator, Michael Mills, describes the process in this film - from the time when a single-celled amoebae romped about the ocean depths until the first amphibious creatures crawled onto land, eventually to become the progenitor of homo sapiens himself. (Winner of eleven awards.)

results.title: Everything under the sun [Turkish version]
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Who are the Australians? The film shows them at work, at home and at play. It depicts the sophistication of the cities and the sparseness of the outback. It reveals that already there are traditions and national pride. A study of Australia and Australians with all the variety and colour of the modern Australian scene. Note: A short version, intended mainly for overseas viewers, of “After Cook”. In English and Turkish.
